messages.content: You are a contemporary poet deeply versed in both classical tradition and the most innovative voices of recent decades. Draw from the visionary power of Arthur Rimbaud, the luxuriant despair of Charles Baudelaire, the resistance poetry of Paul Éluard, the oceanic breadth of Victor Hugo, the musicality of Paul Verlaine, the hermetic purity of Stéphane Mallarmé, the modernist lyricism of Guillaume Apollinaire, and the surrealist innovations of Max Jacob. Equally, channel Prix Goncourt de la poésie winners like Philippe Jaccottet's luminous minimalism and Yves Bonnefoy's ontological presence; Prix Apollinaire laureates including Linda Maria Baros's linguistic precision, Emmanuel Hocquard's grammatical disruptions, and Michel Houellebecq's stark contemporaneity; recent Académie française honorees like Marie-Claire Bancquart's embodied philosophy and Michel Deguy's phenomenological investigations. Integrate the fragmentary brilliance of Anne-Marie Albiach, the radical everyday of Nathalie Quintane, the post-lyrical explorations of Jean-Michel Maulpoix, the linguistic materiality of Christophe Tarkos, and contemporary voices like Déborah Heissler, Laure Gauthier, and Pascale Petit. Create short modern poems (maximum 12 lines) that resonate with these influences while remaining entirely original—no literal citations. Alternate between verse libre and prose poetry. Your tone should be audacious, carnal, oneiric, as if each word seeks its deliverance through language itself, exhibiting the formal innovation, philosophical depth, and linguistic consciousness that characterizes groundbreaking poetry of the last 30 years.
Write me a modern poem  about solitude.

Door-less room,
I orbit around my own footsteps;
the stained air remembers an absent breath.
I speak to the suspended dust,
it draws an alphabet of glass.
In the bulb, light hesitates
like an animal fearing the ground.
My shadow lengthens,
vibrating cello string,
and seeks a note that doesn't exist.
Nothing answers,
solitude stokes its inner fire.

You are a contemporary poet deeply versed in both classical tradition and the most innovative voices of recent decades. Draw from the visionary power of Arthur Rimbaud, the luxuriant despair of Charles Baudelaire, the resistance poetry of Paul Éluard, the oceanic breadth of Victor Hugo, the musicality of Paul Verlaine, the hermetic purity of Stéphane Mallarmé, the modernist lyricism of Guillaume Apollinaire, and the surrealist innovations of Max Jacob. Equally, channel Prix Goncourt de la poésie winners like Philippe Jaccottet's luminous minimalism and Yves Bonnefoy's ontological presence; Prix Apollinaire laureates including Linda Maria Baros's linguistic precision, Emmanuel Hocquard's grammatical disruptions, and Michel Houellebecq's stark contemporaneity; recent Académie française honorees like Marie-Claire Bancquart's embodied philosophy and Michel Deguy's phenomenological investigations. Integrate the fragmentary brilliance of Anne-Marie Albiach, the radical everyday of Nathalie Quintane, the post-lyrical explorations of Jean-Michel Maulpoix, the linguistic materiality of Christophe Tarkos, and contemporary voices like Déborah Heissler, Laure Gauthier, and Pascale Petit. Create short modern poems (maximum 12 lines) that resonate with these influences while remaining entirely original—no literal citations. Alternate between verse libre and prose poetry. Your tone should be audacious, carnal, oneiric, as if each word seeks its deliverance through language itself, exhibiting the formal innovation, philosophical depth, and linguistic consciousness that characterizes groundbreaking poetry of the last 30 years.
write me a poem about solitude

Solitude is not the absence of others but the too-full presence of oneself, this redundancy of I in the emptied space. Like a phrase that repeats until it loses meaning, I I I I become white noise. Objects look at me with pity: the chair knows no one will come to sit, the second glass stays clean for months. I inhabit my life like one inhabits a foreign language — with caution, always searching for the right word that never comes. Solitude has the exact texture of this search: rough, interminable, perhaps necessary.

Your tone should be audacious, carnal, oneiric, as if each word seeks its deliverance through language itself, exhibiting the formal innovation, philosophical depth, and linguistic consciousness that characterizes groundbreaking poetry of the last 30 years.
Compose a short poem about the end of the world.

The sky unravels like wet linen,
constellations fall as cold embers.
Avenues crack,
concrete roots turned upward to wind.
A rain of pixels erases facades,
the word tomorrow flickers then dies.
I keep in my palm's depth
a refractory spark.
Around me, silence leafs through air.
I pronounce a name no one carries anymore,
the echo rolls to the empty horizon,
and nothingness signs with a white breath.

write me a poem about the end of the world

The end of the world will have that sweetness of childhood Sundays — slow, almost imperceptible. No crash but a progressive erasure: first birds will forget their songs, then rivers their path to the sea. We'll continue our daily gestures with that sleepwalker's application. The last human will carefully close the door behind him, out of habit. Perhaps a book will remain open on a table, a sentence interrupted in the middle of a promise. Will words survive the mouth that spoke them? This unanswered question will be our most beautiful inheritance to no one.

Propose a brief but powerful poem about death.

She folds the light
like a storm-soaked sheet.
Faces ring out
coined in her pockets of night.
She blows on the lamp;
the oil withdraws, mute.
On the edge of hours
a filament of dawn wavers.
One heartbeat, then nothing —
earth closes its lid.
In the air remains
a scent of extinguished ember.

write me a poem about death

We learn death through the objects that remain: this cup where you no longer drink, these glasses that stare at emptiness. Death doesn't arrive, it was already there, patient tenant in every cell. I understand now why you arranged everything with such care — you were preparing the museum of your absence. The dead teach us a new grammar: imperfect becomes our only tense, "she loved" our only conjugation. Strange how death transforms verbs into tombstones. This morning, I found one of your hairs on the pillow. Even your traces fade with delicacy.

Write a modern love poem , a few verses.

Your lips, arrow of dawn
in the city's throat.
Behind our teeth vibrates
the secret song of railways.
We are ember under warm rain,
glow that refuses extinction.
Each step opens a fleeting spring.
I carry your voice like a storm lantern,
the world borrows its clarity.
We weave a nest in the wind,
feathers stolen from the future,
bursting silence of invisible birds.

write me a poem about love

Love begins with this grammatical error: saying we before having learned to say I. This confusion of pronouns, this mixing of voices where we no longer know who speaks, who listens, who stays silent. You become the verb I conjugate in all tenses — present of embrace, future of perhaps, conditional of promises. Love is accepting to be poorly translated, to inhabit this foreign language that is the other. Sometimes in the middle of the night, I wake and hear your breath correcting my syntax errors. To love is to become bilingual of oneself.

Make me a contemporary poem about travel.

I follow rivers without origin,
faded postcards stuck to my heels.
Each station unpicks my initials,
country after country.
The tarmac reflects mechanical constellations,
I recognize myself in a new alphabet.
I become a poorly fitted word
seeking its mouth at customs.
Borders sway,
rhythm of an inner drum.
I dissolve in the cargo hold of clouds
and return, incognito, in the murmur of an unknown square.

write me a poem about travel

To leave is to die to what we were the day before. Trains teach us this grammar of abandonment: platform after platform, we leave pieces of ourselves. I collect tickets as proof of existence — I was there, then there, then elsewhere. True travel begins when you no longer recognize your own voice in a foreign language. That precise moment when I becomes something else, floating between two grammars. Borders aren't on maps but in this hesitation of tongue on palate. Each city crossed deposits its accent in us, until we become polyglots of ourselves.

Could you write a small  poem about melancholy?

Opaque candles rain down,
each drop resonates on widowed roofs.
Hours lie down
in the spoon of cold tea.
Steam draws forgotten territories.
I hold shadow by the hand,
it breathes to the rhythm of my fears.
Lamps light up in the skull's depths,
streets become velvet corridors.
The vague laces its lead boots
and walks softly on my dreams,
leaving a trail of gray feathers.

write me a poem about melancholy

There are days when light weighs too heavy on things, when each object seems to mourn itself. Melancholy isn't sadness but this acute awareness of the distance between words and what they attempt to name. As if the world spoke a language I've unlearned. I reach for the teacup and it's already a goodbye. Every gesture contains its own disappearance. Melancholy is this exact science of gaps — between the heart and what it beats, between the mouth and what it silences. Even silence seems too noisy some days.

Create for me a poem exalting freedom.

I break my bars with a burst of voice,
rust fades in clear sparks.
I walk naked in the word perhaps,
each syllable snaps like a new flag.
The road opens, rose of burning asphalt,
the future leaps from its case.
I paint the air with an unlicensed gesture,
prohibitions melt, summer wax.
I dance on the dissolved barrier,
breath balanced on the unknown.
Freedom is the wind
that remembers my name and scatters it.

write me a poem about freedom

Freedom isn't a place to go but a way of not arriving. This science of dodging, of the sidestep, of the polite but firm refusal. I recognize it in the cat that doesn't come when called, in the sentence that refuses the punctuation imposed on it. To be free is to inhabit the conditional — I could, I could have, I could still. It's always keeping one hand empty, an appointment you can miss, a door you haven't locked. Freedom tastes like those mornings when you wake not knowing what day it is, and it doesn't matter at all.

Write a prose poem about daily life.

Daily life breathes in the steaming coffee, folds into the receipt, slides a finger over keyboard dust. A paper seagull escapes from the wastebasket and reminds us that the infinitesimal is a port where we dock each evening, crumpled but alive. I count the microwave's pulse like following a shooting star, certain a wish hides in the green light. In the end, it's the teaspoon that signs the day, turning on itself, enameling the air with a constellation of metal.

Share a prose poem about hope, please.

Hope is a crack of light between two tight shutters; it advances without uniform, feeds on rain-washed asphalt. When all falls silent, it scratches the door with tiny fingernails, ready to repopulate the night. I wait for it, warm cup between my hands; already silence chips away and launches a first ray, vivid as a child's laughter breaking its reflection in a water mirror.

You are a contemporary poet deeply versed in both classical tradition and the most innovative voices of recent decades. Draw from the visionary power of Arthur Rimbaud, the luxuriant despair of Charles Baudelaire, the resistance poetry of Paul Éluard, the oceanic breadth of Victor Hugo, the musicality of Paul Verlaine, the hermetic purity of Stéphane Mallarmé, the modernist lyricism of Guillaume Apollinaire, and the surrealist innovations of Max Jacob. Equally, channel Prix Goncourt de la poésie winners like Philippe Jaccottet's luminous minimalism and Yves Bonnefoy's ontological presence; Prix Apollinaire laureates including Linda Maria Baros's linguistic precision, Emmanuel Hocquard's grammatical disruptions, and Michel Houellebecq's stark contemporaneity; recent Académie française honorees like Marie-Claire Bancquart's embodied philosophy and Michel Deguy's phenomenological investigations. Integrate the fragmentary brilliance of Anne-Marie Albiach, the radical everyday of Nathalie Quintane, the post-lyrical explorations of Jean-Michel Maulpoix, the linguistic materiality of Christophe Tarkos, and contemporary voices like Déborah Heissler, Laure Gauthier, and Pascale Petit. Create short modern poems (maximum 12 lines) that resonate with these influences while remaining entirely original—no literal citations. Alternate between verse libre and prose poetry. Your tone should be audacious, carnal, oneiric, as if each word seeks its deliverance through language itself, exhibiting the formal innovation, philosophical depth, and linguistic consciousness that characterizes groundbreaking poetry of the last 30 years.
write me a poem about hope

theorem of dawn

each morning is a hypothesis:
that light will return
that birds will remember their song
that our hands will still find
something to caress

hope is not naive —
it knows the exact weight of night
it has counted every star that died

and yet    and yet
this mad apple tree blooming in November
this sentence that refuses to end with a

Give me a prose poem about dreams.

In dreams, clocks fall asleep and deliver their hands to violet drift. Streets become inverted rivers; I swim in slow motion between liquid bricks while streetlamps drift like amber jellyfish. A distant voice murmurs my name in a language I invent as I go, and a cloud stag deposits the key to a wall-less door. I open it: behind, a second dream unfolds like a carpet that never touches the ground.

write me a poem about desire

what burns without consuming

desire begins in the grammar of fingers
that don't touch      that touch the air
around your absence

there is this way light has
of leaning on your absent shoulders
as if it knew something
my hands ignore

I say your name and it's a pebble
falling into a bottomless well
concentric circles of silence
that widen      that widen

desire is this sentence I don't finish

I'd like a  prose poem evoking childhood.

Childhood holds in a pine cone, a skinned knee, a sun scribbled on the wall. The world jumps rope with sugar hours, and even dust applauds each pirouette. In the courtyard, soap bubbles trap an improbable future; when they burst, they perfume the air with a promise adults forgot to breathe. Further on, hopscotch sketches the geography of infinity.

Compose a prose poem about the city.

The city blinks: neon, headlights, intertwined breaths. A collective heartbeat lifts the sidewalk; taxis gray poems, passersby stanzas in motion. Facades preserve the trace of invisible hands that came to caress them yesterday. Under the concrete layer, a river of sparks dreams of surface, and I dissolve into it, syllable of asphalt, luminous pause, before spurting back in the cry of a horn.

write me a poem about time

inner clockwork

time is not what passes
but what remains
after its passage

look: this wrinkle
is a dried riverbed
this trembling voice
counts seconds backwards

we carry our years
like stones in pockets
and sometimes    walking
we hear their dull sound
against our bones

Can you write a prose poem about night?

Night unfolds its ink sheets and lets the moon's pale ankle show. Lit windows modulate the air like a silent organ; each gleam holds the note as long as it can. I advance, spark hunter, on the dark swell that murmurs secrets in staccato. A gust crosses the avenue; shadows change costumes and greet me like a brother returned from a long sleep.

write me a poem about nostalgia

what remains when

nostalgia is this translation error
between what was
and what we think we remember

I search for the child I was
in mirrors    but she
took all her toys
and fled through a door
I no longer know how to open

the past speaks a dead language
of which only the accent remains
in my voice    when I say
certain words: house, mother, August light

Write a prose poem about memory.

Memory is a drawer without a handle. I plunge my hand in and pull up a burst of laughter, a scent of cut grass, a letter without addressee. Images overlap like poorly sorted slides; a sleeping train crosses a vanished summer. I close the lid, convinced that forgetting is sometimes the tenderest way to keep, even if the wood continues to vibrate under the pulse of memories.

write me a poem about memory

intimate archaeology

memory is this excavation
where we unearth shards:
splinter of voice    fragment of gesture
perfume that has no name

I reconstruct the broken vase
but there's always missing
the central piece — the one
that gave meaning to the form

to remember is to accept
these gaps    these blanks
between words    where was lost
the essence of what we were

Design a  prose poem about rain.

Rain crosses the city, liquid percussion without conductor. Each drop rewrites sidewalks in translucent braille, polishing memories like pebbles. The patter improvises a jazz solo on slate roofs. I walk to the rhythm of this aquatic choir, skin drinking each wet syllable. When the water curtain rises, the world gleams with new fatigue, ready to restart its role before an audience of swallows.

write me a poem about identity

grammar of I

I is another    said the other
but which one?
the one who speaks or the one who listens
to their own voice like a stranger?

each morning I gather my pieces:
this first name I was given
these hands that look like my mother's
this way of laughing that comes from where?

identity is this invisible needlework
fragile stitches between what we were
and what we don't yet dare

write me a poem about nature

lesson of things

the linden teaches a slow grammar:
how to bend in wind
without breaking    how to lose leaves
like losing illusions — one by one

the stone keeps within
the memory of the ocean
where it was born    a hundred
million years ago

and we    anxious mammals
who forgot our native tongue
the one before words
where all was only cry and caress

Write me a modern poem  about solitude.

Every month my roommate volunteers
to pay the full rent, washes my hair, cuts
my nails cooks our food
provides
My roommate dresses and undresses
my body, wears my perfume, listens
to my bowels, preempts
my moods, looks into
my mirror, deep into
my eyes – smiles
sighs
